title: Mastering product strategy and growing as a PM | Maggie Crowley (Toast, Drift, TripAdvisor)
key_insights: When working with combustible founders, start meetings by aligning on goals and success metrics to maintain focus
Older employees should show up with curiosity, positive energy, and passionate engagement - people notice energy more than wrinkles
Build credibility by getting closer to customers than anyone else in the room
Culture becomes more important as companies become more distributed - it's what happens when the boss isn't around
Consider taking pay cuts to work part-time as you age - companies get their money's worth from your institutional wisdom
Anxiety equals uncertainty times powerlessness - create an anxiety balance sheet to make it tangible
Older brains excel at connecting dots and systemic thinking, while younger brains are fast and focused - the combination is powerful
Despair equals suffering minus meaning - add more meaning to reduce despair

memorable_quotes: I was mentoring Brian, but he was also my boss. I was 52, the average age was 26. I had to be both wise and curious, and often the dumbest person in the room.
Your painful life lessons are the raw material for your future wisdom.
People won't notice your wrinkles as much as they'll notice your energy.

summary: Chip Conley shares his remarkable journey from boutique hotelier to Airbnb's oldest employee, offering practical wisdom on thriving in tech at any age, working effectively with founder-CEOs, and reframing midlife as a period of growth rather than decline. The conversation provides actionable frameworks for managing anxiety, building culture, and leveraging intergenerational collaboration.
